http://vocab.ieawindtask32.org/wind-lida: IEA Wind Task 32 Wind Lidar Ontology
This glossary is produced and maintained by IEA Wind Task 32.
Suggestions for additions or changes should be made through the glossary repository at https://github.com/IEA-Wind-Task-32/wind-lidar-glossary.
IEA Wind Task 32 Wind Lidar Ontology
Ontological representation of wind lidar supporting development of modular tools and processes for wind lidars.

column7: skos:definition@en
column17: skos:editorialNote@en

column7: A unit for parameter or variable being defined.
Ways that wind lidar data can be processed to extract useful data
Approach to processing wind lidar data to estimate a wind vector at one or more points in the domain sampled by the lidar

VAD is a method of analyzing data from a complete conical scan whereby many closely spaced azimuthal points may be sampled by the lidar, and the data are used to estimate the wind speed at each height using a statistical fitting method.
column17: The VAD method is described in Lhermitte (1966) and Browning and Wexler (1968).

column7: Ways that wind lidar can be used

The combination of three elements: 1. Outcome-driven data requirements (as opposed to constraint-driven requirements, see 1st generation sensor / 1st generation measurements); 2. The measurement method selected to fulfil them; 3. The operational conditions that determine the performance of the method with respect to accuracy

A series of wind measurements made at discrete vertical locations, aping a met mast. These can be implemented using many approaches including Crossed RHI (XRHI) and other dual- or triple-lidar measurement
Wind lidar generic design structure
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The Chassis module is responsible for the various mounting solutions for the lidar, including, but not limited to, mounting on a nacelle, a meteorological tower, the ground, a floating platform, or a mobile structure
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The control module is the interface between the external controller (human or machine) and the lidar system
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The system of devices and software that transmit and receive data and commands to and from the lidar device
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The signal processing module is used to convert the data acquired by the lidar into a data product
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The Storage module is responsible for saving data in the lidar system which will be accessed by users at some future time.
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The interlocks are a dispersed set of safety systems that prevent or mitigate potentially dangerous activities.
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The optics module is designed to alter the original laser beam into radiation with desired specification that can be sent to the target and received by the detector properly."
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The system of lenses, mirrors and other optical and mechanical components that emit and receive laser light
The aperture through which laser light is emitted and received
Characteristic optical diameter of the lidar telescope
All-fiber transmission Lidar system
column17: True if lidar is all-fiber

column7: The photonics module is the source of emitted light that will be used for the measurements.
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: An assembly to gather and detect incident light
Semiconductor light sensor.
The gain of the photodetector transimpedance amplifier.
The voltage noise of the photodetector transimpedance amplifier.
Bragg cell diffracting and shifting frequency of the light using sound waves (radio-frequency). Produces a pulsed output beam.
column17: Only pulsed lidar

column7: An assembly to amplify the outgoing laser light signal without coverting it into an electrical signal.
column17: Definition based on Wikipedia entry at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_amplifier"

column7: An optical assembly to split a laser beam into two or more beams.
column17: Definition based on Wikipedia entry at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beam_splitter

column7: An assembly to generate and manage laser light.
A semiconductor component to generate laser light of a defined frequency.
The nominal wavelength of the laser source. This is defined in units of meters, e.g., 1450E-9 m for a near-infrared laser source.
The Power Module is responsible for supplying power to the entire lidar system, including motors, lasers, sensors, and detectors.
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: Uninterruptible power supply (UPS)
An energy storage component
The battery voltage. Units are Volts.
The total stored energy in the battery voltage. Units are Amp Hours (Ah)
The scanner orients the beam with respect to the housing and other parts of the lidar system. The scanner may be capable of one or more degrees of freedom.
column17: Definition based on the OpenLidar module definitions at https://github.com/e-WindLidar/OpenLidarModuleDefinitions

column7: The azimuth servo motor drives the scanner in the azimuthal direction
The maximum rate of operation of the servo motor in the azimuthal direction
The azimuth servo motor drives the scanner in the elevation direction
The maximum rate of operation of the servo motor in the elevation direction
Mirrors modifying the beam path between the telescope and atmosphere.
Specific implementations of wind lidar technologies.
One of many different types of system that can be used to perform convergent scan geometries. Originally referred to the DTU-led windscanner.eu project.
column17: Describing a wind lidar unit as "a windscanner" is insufficient information to uniquely describe it's capabilities.

column7: Type of free-standing lidar device intended for use as a forward-looking lidar mounted on a wind turbine nacelle
column17: Describing a wind lidar unit as 'a wind iris' is insufficient information to uniquely describe it's capabilities.

column7: Wind lidar instances
wind lidar serial number
The type of lidar device
The means by which a lidar makes a measurement of the wind
The line along which lidar signals are emitted and backscattered to be detected by the system.
The time taken for a lidar pulse to be emitted, interact with the atmosphere in a probe volume such that it is backscattered, and return to be detected by the system.

The region characterised by the wind lidar. Corresponds to the region penetrated by the various beam orientations / lines of sight and probe volumes where intermediate data are acquired to produce a final measurement.

In the case of scanning lidar, the probe is a laser pulse emitted along a line of sight whose orientation is determined by the configuration of the lidar. In the case of a continuous wave lidar, the probe is a region of relatively elevated sensitivity along the line of sight determined by the optical focus of the system.
The volume in which the probe interacts with the atmosphere resulting in the measurement of a radial velocity.

An intermediate variable (see intermediate data), the radial velocity is the radial component of the wind velocity vector relative to the location of the lidar measuring it. It is the projection of the wind velocity vector onto the line of sight, directly measured by observing the Doppler shift of the backscattered laser pulse emitted along the line of sight.

1. The arrangement of a sequence of scanning lidar configurations that require the lidar beam to be scanned or swept between a number of different orientations. The scan geometry ensures measurements are acquired throughout the measurement volume sufficient for wind field reconstruction. The sequence of beam orientations may be repeated to acquire a time series of final data acquired from each iteration. Scans may be performed in stop-stare or sweep-stare mode. 2. The collection of lines of sight / beam orientations along which the lidar is programmed to emit its probe.
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: Measurements made by a single lidar.
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: A scan geometry comprised of a single beam orientation.

Line-of-sight data are acquired while the beam remains stationary in one of the pre-determined orientations comprising the scan geometry. No data are acquired while the beam is moved to its next position."@en ;
Line-of-sight data are acquired continuously as the beam is scanned between pre-determined positions.
A simple scan geometry entails variation in beam orientation in a single degree of freedom
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: A simple scan geometry with variable azimuth angle
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: A scan geometry in which the azimuth angle of the beam is varied over the full 360 degree range of possible azimuth angles. Wind speed and direction values can be obtained through a wind field reconstruction process, for example by assuming a sinusoidal dependence on azimuth angle.

A scan geometry in which the azimuth angle of the beam is varied over less than the full 360 degree range of possible azimuth angles. Wind speed and direction values can potentially be obtained through a wind field reconstruction process, for example by assuming a sinusoidal dependence on azimuth angle.

A scan geometry in which the azimuth angle of the beam is varied by 90 degrees over the full 360 degree range of possible azimuth angles. Wind speed and direction values can be obtained through a wind field reconstruction process, for example by assuming a sinusoidal dependence on azimuth angle.
A simple scan geometry with variable elevation angle
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: Scans can be made where the beam is swept through a vertical slice by varying the elevation angle but not the azimuth angle. These scans are also known as range-height-indicator (RHI) scans. This scan geometry may be used to look at details in the flow in the cross-sectional surface sampled by the scan

Scans can be made where the beam is swept through a vertical slice by varying the elevation angle but not the azimuth angle. These scans are also known as range-height-indicator (RHI) scans. This scan geometry may be used to look at details in the flow in the cross-sectional surface sampled by the scan
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: Scans can be made where the beam is swept through an arbitrary combination of elevation and azimuth angles to follow a desired trajectory. This could be considered analagous to tracking the path of a flying bird from a fixed location.
In a sequential scan, simple and/or compound scans are executed one after another by the same device to reveal flow characteristics.
column17: The scanning geometry taxonomy is based on Figure 3 in NREL/TP-5000-64634 https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy16osti/64634.pdf

column7: Coordinated measurements made in the same region by multiple lidar. Measurements may or may not be synchronised in time.

A measurement configuration involving multiple lidar units which are operated in a coordinated and synchronised manner so that their beams converge and intersect at a succession of probe volumes. If three or more lidar units are used, it is possible to characterise the wind velocity vector in the probe volume where the beams intersect within the limitations prescribed by the probe length, sampling interval, and scan geometry.
Wind lidar-specific parameters.
A measure of lidar return signal strength
column17: Often used interchangably with SNR

column7: A measure of lidar return signal strength
column17: Often used interchangably with CNR

column7: The angle between the line of sight of the lidar and a reference vector on the datum plane.
column17: The reference vector from which the azimuth is defined is often true north, but could be some other defined vector.

column7: The angle between the line of sight of the lidar and the datum plane.

The nominal height above the datum plane at which a windfield reconstruction process returns a wind speed. Often used for vertically-profiling wind lidars for comparison to point wind speed measurements from an anemometer.
The height of the datum plane above sea level
column17: Sea level should be defined on a project basis and is out of scope of this schema.

column7: The horizontal plane from which the measurement height is defined, e.g., lidar window, local ground, a platform top surface, or other reference.
A distinguishing feature used to recognise or define the datum plane from which the measurement height is defined
